journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Reinforced Plastics and Composites

title-group.article-title: Preparation and self-healing performance of epoxy composites with microcapsules and tungsten (VI) chloride catalyst

article-meta.aff: 1College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Northeast Petroleum University, China
2Center for Composite Materials, Harbin Institute of Technology, China

author-notes.corresp: Li Haiyan, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Northeast Petroleum University, Daqing, P.R. China, 163318 Email: lhy06b@163.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Self-healing materials are inspired by biological systems in which damage triggers an autonomic healing response. Epoxy resin-based self-healing system was demonstrated using tungsten (VI) chloride catalyst with a co-activator (phenylacetylene) that initiates ring-opening metathesis polymerization of dicyclopentadiene. The microcapsules with diameter of 200 ± 40 µm and average wall thickness of 5 µm were synthesized. Crack trigger process was analyzed by using finite element methods, the results indicated that the crack will be attracted toward the microcapsules when the wall thickness of microcapsules is in the range of 5–20 µm. The mechanism of tungsten (VI) chloride catalyze polymerization was studied. Environmental stability of tungsten (VI) chloride was investigated. Self-activated and self-healing samples were prepared and the healing efficiency was evaluated. It was found the concentration of catalyst have a significant impact on the virgin properties of the composites and the healing efficiency. The highest healing efficiency 64.9% was obtained with 15 wt% catalyst at self-activated samples. In the case of 10 wt% tungsten (VI) chloride and 10 wt% microcapsules, in situ self-healing sample yielded a healing efficiency of approximately 38.0%.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Polymer composites are used as structural materials for various applications including aerospace, automotive, electronics fields, and so on. The suffered stresses of these materials under normal use or exposure to harsh environment lead to cracking of the matrix. Microcrack is one of the fatal deteriorations generated in service, which would bring about catastrophic failure of the composites and significantly shorten the lifetime of structures.1–6 Self-healing materials are capable to repair autonomically the microcracks, restore structural integrity, and increase the lifetime of the materials.

Self-healing approaches include remendable systems,7 hollow fibers,8,9 microencapsulation of healing agents,10–28 and microvascular network systems.29–34 Chen et al.7 represented the remendable self-healing systems synthesized by cross-linked polymeric materials with multi-furan and multi-maleimide. At temperatures above 120°C, the ‘intermonomer’ linkages disconnect but then reconnect upon cooling. This process is fully reversible and can be used to restore fractured parts of the polymers. However, the application of these polymers as the matrix of advanced composites is limited due to the low glass temperatures.

Hollow glass fibers infused with either healing or curing agent were placed at critical damage interfaces in a carbon or glass fiber reinforced composite. The healing fibers rupture and release the healing agent into the damage zone under stresses. Although this technique can fully restore the strength of the damaged composite, the hollow glass fibers may act as initiation for composites failure because their sizes (on millimeter scale) are much larger than those of the reinforcing fibers in composites. Instead, Pang et al.8 used hollow glass fiber (with an external diameter of 15 µm and an internal diameter of 5 µm) to minimize the detrimental effect associated with large diameter fibers, but the filling of healing agent into such fine tubes becomes rather difficult.

Self-healing system with microcapsules was first proposed by White and coworkers,1 which consists of microencapsulated dicyclopentadiene (DCPD) healing agent and Grubbs’ catalyst particles embedded in a polymer matrix. When cracks propagate through the matrix, the microcapsules will be broken and ruptures and the DCPD is released into the crack plane through capillary action. Poly-DCPD is formed in the crack plane resulting from the ring-opening metathesis polymerization (ROMP) reaction of DCPD initiated by Grubbs’ catalyst to restore the virgin structural properties of the polymer matrix. Up to 90% of the materials virgin fracture toughness can be restored by this method. However, this system has limitation including catalyst availability, cost, environmental toxicity, stability, and materials processing, which motivates the search for other catalyst and healing agent systems.35–40

Recently, a three-dimensional microvascular network system is designed and embedded into the substrate or coating.29–34 Through capillary action, monomer flows from the network channels into the crack plane and polymerized by a catalyst embedded in the composites or coating. This circular repair for damage zone can be achieved.

In this paper, we report a self-healing system with tungsten (VI) chloride (WCl6) catalyst and poly(urea-formaldehyde) (PUF) containing DCPD microcapsules. WCl6 is a cost-effective alternative and has a melting point of Tm = 275°C, which is significantly higher than that of Grubbs’ catalyst (Tm = 153°C). The effect of WCl6 on self-healing performance was studied. At the same time, we study the effect of wall thickness of microcapsules on the crack propagating process, which is the key to achieve self-healing performance.

sec.title: Preparation and surface modification of microcapsules
sec.p: PUF microcapsules were prepared by an improved method reported by our former study.41–44 At first, U-F pre-polymer solution was prepared at pH = 8–9 condition. DCPD (20 ml), phenylacetylene (0.2 g), and nonylphenol (0.12 g) were dissolved into U-F pre-polymer solution (40 ml). Emulsified sodium dodecylbenzene sulfonate (DBS, 0.03 g) and resorcinol (0.5 g) were added into solution. After being stirred for 15–30 min at a rate of 500 rpm, the pH of the solution was adjusted slowly to 3.0–4.0 by 10 wt% sulfuric acid solution. Then the solution was heated to 60°C and persist 3 h. The microcapsules were washed with deionized water and acetone, filtered and air-dried for 24 h. The prepared microcapsules were surface modified with 3-aminopropyltriethoxy silane-coupling agent (KH550) by our reported method42 in order to improve the interface adhesion between microcapsules and resin matrix.

sec.title: Preparation of self-healing epoxy samples
sec.p: Two types of epoxy samples were fabricated: Self-activated samples containing WCl6, but no healing agent, and in situ self-healing samples containing both WCl6 and microcapsules. These microcapsules contained DCPD, phenylacetylene and nonylphenol. For self-activated samples, E-51 epoxy resin with 10 wt% triethylenetetramine curing agent were degassed and allowed to react for 30 min at 25°C to reduce the concentration of free amines prior to the addition of WCl6. WCl6 was then added to the epoxy resin and the mixture was stirred. For in situ self-healing samples, microcapsules were also added to the mixture. The mixture was cooled down to 5°C in refrigerator to increase the viscosity which prevents WCl6 particles from precipitation. The E-51 epoxy can be slowly cured at 5°C. After 2 h, the mixture was cured for 24 h at 25°C, followed by postcuring at 35°C for 24 h.

sec.title: Characterization
sec.p: Surface morphology and wall thickness of microcapsules, fracture surface morphology of composites were observed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM; XL 30 ESEM-FEG, PHILIPS). Samples were prepared on an aluminium slice, dried in a vacuum oven, and sputter-coated with gold-palladium.

sec.title: Mechanical assessment of healing performance
sec.p:
Tapered double-cantilever beam (TDCB) samples were adopted to evaluate healing performance, the geometry of TDCB was shown in Figure 1.12 Fracture toughness KIC is calculated by (1) For TDCB samples, there is α = 11.2 × 103 m−2/3 and PC represents the critical fracture load. Figure 1.
Tapered double-cantilever beam (TDCB) samples geometry (dimension in mm).

The healing performance is evaluated by the healing efficiency which is measured by carefully controlled fracture experiments for both the virgin and healed materials. The healing efficiency is written as: (2)
This required knowledge of only the critical fracture load PC.

Fracture specimens were tested under displacement control, using pin loading and 5 µm/s displacement rate. Five samples were tested for each case. For self-activated samples, the samples contain the catalyst phase and the healing agent is manually injected into the crack after samples fracture. Virgin specimens were tested to failure, giving the critical fracture load PC virgin, and then the fractured two pieces were jointed together and a healing solution of approximately 100 μl was injected between the fracture planes. The healing solution was prepared by mixing 1 g DCPD, 12 mg nonylphenol, and 6 mg phenylacetylene. Then the samples were clamped in a vacuum oven for 24 h at 50°C. After healing, the samples were tested again and the healed fracture load PC healed was obtained. The healing efficiency was calculated according to equation (2).

Similar method was used to test the in situ samples, but no additional healing agent was manually applied in these cases. Rather, healing agent delivery is accomplished autonomically via fracture of microcapsules contained within the sample.

sec.title: Characterization of microcapsules
sec.p:
Figure 2(a) shows the SEM micrographs of microcapsules samples. The surface of microcapsules is rough and scraggly which can increase the surface areas of microcapsules and enhance surface adhesion. Figure 2(b) shows the micrographs of ruptured microcapsules. There are healing agent outflow indicating that the PUF successfully microencapsule DCPD. In this study, the mean diameter of the prepared microcapsules is 200 ± 40 µm, which is an optimal size for self-healing system according to the report from Brown.12 Figure 2(c) shows the SEM micrographs of one ruptured microcapsule and the average wall thickness of the microcapsules sample is 5 µm. Figure 2.
Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) micrograph of microcapsules sample before (a) and after (b and c) rupture.

sec.title: Analysis of crack propagates
sec.p:
The wall thickness of microcapsules has important effect on the mechanical triggering process. If capsule walls are too thick, it will not be ruptured when the crack approaches, whereas capsules with very thin walls will break during processing. The effect of wall thickness on crack propagates approach was analyzed by finite element methods. An illustrative result from this study is presented in Figure 3 which shows the path of an approaching crack. We define the microcapsules size is 200 µm and wall thickness is 2, 5, 10, 20, 30, 50 µm in the model according with characterization results of microcapsules. The elastic module of epoxy resin and PUF wall materials are 3.4 GPa and 3.7 GPa, respectively. The Poisson’s ratios of the wall materials and matrix are equal (0.3). According to the symmetry of specimen, plan structure can be employed to calculate using the commercial software ANSYS. During the procedure of mesh division, Plane42 is used in bulk material and Plane82 is used in capsule shell. State analysis is applied to the model, in which the boundary layer between bulk material and capsule shell is assumed perfectly joined. By the request of the analysis, the crack, the sphere, and the surrounding matrix are subjected to random load, perpendicular to the crack plane. The stress distribution of the model is solved. The stress distribution in the equatorial plane of the sphere was shown in Figure 3(a)–(f), in the same loads, when the wall thickness of microcapsules is 2, 5, 10, and 20 µm, the stress distribution near the microcapsules is larger than surrounding matrix, which will attract the crack propagating to microcapsule and then rupture it, the crack will be attracted toward the microcapsules, a necessary condition rupture and the triggering of the healing process. At the same time, the thinner of the wall thickness the larger of the stress distribution near the microcapsules. When the wall thickness of microcapsules is 30, 50 µm, the stress distributions near the microcapsules and surrounding matrix are almost similar, which has the possibility that the crack propagate random and thus cannot achieve self-healing. Based on the above analysis, the wall thickness of microcapsules should be less than 30 µm. When the wall thickness is 2 µm, we found it was easily broken during processing, so we think the optimum range should be 5–20 µm. We prepared the microcapsules with average 5 µm wall thickness as shown as in Figure 2(c). Wall thickness of microcapsules can be controlled by adjusting the ratio between wall materials and core materials or adjusting stir rate and so on in the process of microcapsules preparation. Figure 3.
Stress distribution in the equatorial plane of the microcapsule with wall thickness 2 µm (a), 5 µm (b), 10 µm (c), 20 µm (d), 30 µm (e), and 50 µm (f).

sec.title: Mechanism of WCl6 catalyze polymerization
sec.p: WCl6 itself is not the active catalyst but rather a catalyst precursor. The key step to form an active catalyst is the alkylation of the tungsten, which is usually accomplished by the addition of a separate co-activator. The most effective co-activators are aggressive alkylating agents such as organoaluminium compounds, but they are also extremely sensitive to air or other impurities. Here, the phenylacetylene was chosen, which has been shown to be an effective co-activator with WCl6 even in air.45 Nonylphenol was used as the dissolution agent of WCl6, which is necessary because self-healing is triggered by the dissolution of the catalyst into the healing agent. At the same time, complex compound was formed with high catalytic performance as shown in chemical formula.

The mechanism of WCl6 catalyze polymerization are shown in Figure 4. Metal carbene of active catalyst firstly reacts with the double bond of DCPD to form the cyclobutane structure. Then, cyclobutane structures rupture and form new metal carbene which initiate the ring-opening metathesis polymerization (ROMP) polymerization continually. At last, the Poly-DCPD was formed. Figure 4.
The action mechanism of ring-opening metathesis polymerization (ROMP) of dicyclopentadiene (DCPD) catalyzed by tungsten (VI) chloride (WCl6).

The environmental stability of WCl6 was studied. After WCl6 was exposed to air (20°C, 50% relative humidity) for 24 h, all WCl6 completely converts to either WO2Cl2 or other tungsten oxide. It is difficult to analyze the exact structure because of the complicated produce. At this time, it has no catalytic function. Figure 5 is the SEM images of WCl6 before and after oxidation. The strip crystal structure was formed after oxidation as shown in Figure 5(b). To determine the optimal catalyst concentration that provides for high healing efficiency without diminishing virgin fracture toughness, five sets of self-activated samples were manufactured with different WCl6 concentration. Virgin and healed fracture toughness values and the corresponding healing efficiency have been measured and listed in Table 1. Figure 5.
Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) of tungsten (VI) chloride (WCl6) before (a) and after (b) oxidation. Table 1.
Virgin and healed fracture toughness values and the corresponding healing efficiency of self-activated samples
WCl6 concentration wt% Fracture toughness KIC (MPa · m1/2) Healing efficiency %
Virgin Healed
0 1.34 0 0
5 1.10 0.42 38.2
10 0.77 0.46 59.7
15 0.57 0.37 64.9
20 0.45 0.27 60.0
WCl6: tungsten (VI) chloride.

The healing efficiency increased with the addition of more catalyst. The highest healing efficiency 64.9% was obtained with 15 wt% catalyst at self-activated samples. There are little increase for healing efficiency when the catalyst concentration beyond 10 wt% which due to the 10 wt% concentration is nearly enough for the healing agent polymerization. However, the virgin fracture toughness decreases with the addition of catalyst concentration. Considering the high healing efficiency and low diminishment of virgin fracture toughness synthetically, the catalyst concentration of 10 wt% was appropriate and the healing efficiency of 59.7% can be obtained.

In situ self-healing experiments were performed with 10 wt% microcapsules and 10 wt% WCl6. It is reported that the optimal microcapsule concentration is 10 wt% because of maximized DCPD delivery and near maximum virgin fracture toughness.11 The maximum healing performance was measured 38.0%. A representative load-displacement curve for virgin and healed self-healing composite sample are plotted in Figure 6. The self-healing efficiency is lower than that of self-activated sample. Several behaviors were observed, which may be contributed to poor healing performance. The main problem was that WCl6 tended to aggregate severely which led to non-uniform catalyst distribution. Additionally, the catalyst clearly had not dissolved entirely into the monomer before the polymerization stopped, and the slow dissolution of WCl6 hindered the reaction. Figure 6.
Load-displacement curve of virgin and healed self-healing composite sample.

The SEM micrographs of the fractured surfaces of the self-healing epoxy specimens are shown in Figure 7(a). Figure 7(b) is fractured surface micrographs of neat epoxy resin for comparison with that of self-healed one. From Figure 7(a), we can see that there are large numbers of the poly-DCPD films (denoted by arrowhead) in the fracture surface. However, poly-DCPD film does not cover the resin matrix completely, which depends on the position of catalyst. Figure 7.
Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) micrographs: (a) fractured surfaces of the self-healing epoxy specimens, contents of microcapsules and tungsten (VI) chloride (WCl6) are all 10 wt% and (b) fractured surfaces of neat epoxy resin.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The wall thickness of microcapsules plays an important factor which affects the mechanical triggering process. Crack trigger process was analyzed by using finite element methods, the results indicated that the optimum range of microcapsules wall thickness should be 5–20 µm, which will be appropriate for achieving self-healing performance. For the self-healing system, the highest healing efficiency of 64.9% was obtained with 15 wt% catalyst for self-activated samples. However, the more catalysts concentrations provide a significant loss of virgin fracture toughness. By optimizing the concentrations of catalyst and microcapsules, in situ self-healing experiments using 10 wt% WCl6 and 10 wt% microcapsules containing DCPD healing agent, phenylacetylene co-activator, and nonylphenol solvent yields approximately 38.0% healing efficiency. The environmental stability of WCl6 was studied. When WCl6 was exposed to air for 24 h, all WCl6 completely converts to either WO2Cl2 or other tungsten oxide. It has no catalytic function. Further research is required to improve the healing efficiency by more effective co-activators and solvent of WCl6 and more uniform WCl6 dispersion.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
